author: LAPhill
content:
Shout out to @Tim O’Sullivan for not only finally solving my hum issues, but dialing in the workflow in my room to a whole other level. He wired up all my pedals, synths, and preamps to a couple of patch bays so I can throw signal all around the room in any order (complete with right-angle cables so I can use them with the desk doors closed). He also built MIDI lines to send clock from my DAW to the pedals and we upgraded the room to Mio MIDI-over-Ethernet units. Several other creature comforts that allow me to think less, like routing a headphone connection underneath the right side of my desk instead of the left where my interface is, adding a second one by the piano, and ready-to-go cables for guitars, synths and microphones already plugged in where they need to be.

I'm going to run out of reasons not to call this studio "done" soon.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I think the whole “same DI from pro tools” strategy for things like microphones and amps is really overrated and misses the point about how humans make music.  I’ve long said re-amping is good only as an effect, because how an amp responds will change how a player plays. 

For that same reason, I like just doing a couple of takes for each mic with the singer. Sure they might sing differently… but isn’t that part of the point? I’m interested in which microphone brings out the best in the singer and is inspiring to use. If I want specs I can look at a frequency plot.

So, to update this: spent most of my time being a runner and doing runner things. We had an issue with an inadequate scented candle, so to target we went. The engineer who ran the session is one of the few I’m chill with, so he very briefly introduced me to swizz as “Evan, the runner who makes some dope synth pop” (alicia was warming up, but swizz was real down to earth and nice. very focused) and i actually got to catch a couple glimpses of what they were doing in the studio when I wasn’t calling restaurants and polling my vegan friends for food recs. author: BatMeckley
content:
You clearly have put in many years so hopefully the measuring and the protractor gives you that extra push to get to where you’re hoping to go 🤍.

Just trying to put context in here for the people that haven’t. None of the mixes in the mix off we had on the forum earlier hinged on the  single digit adjustments of the angle of the toe in of the speakers. It’s important to spend our times wisely on the things that matter most.

Virtually every kid I know that started on a $4000 guitar is less of a player than the kid that started on a squire. There’s something to learning the skills and then upgrading the tools.

author: peterlabberton
content:
So far I’m using the S1 to:

a) have hands on control when mixing drums, as I’ve got a handful of parallel compression and distortion auxes. I’ve made it work with a keyboard and mouse, but being able to have one hand on an audio track fader and the other on the return of a parallel effect is great.

b) setup VCAs for my whole mix and, once I’ve got things in a good spot, close all the pro tools windows so I’m more focused on just listening, and play the mix back and write automation.

These are both just things I’ve missed about working on a console, and I’m glad to be able to reincorporate them into my workflow.

And to put the EQ on, I sent my main PT output to a virtual output, and have the EQ on there in Console, assigned to the monitors.

author: cian riordan
content: If you're doing vocals on hardwood or tile floor, rugs are great for nabbing first reflections off the floor. Most of what is bouncing back into the microphone is in that slappy high end area and will likely sound bad. With a guitar cab, the microphone will sit quite a bit lower to the ground -- so in theory this idea is even more useful. However, program-material depending, its likely whatever is coming out of the speaker is going to drastically overpower what gets slapped up from the floor. If there's a rug around I'll typically use it for these situations.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Final note on the back wall (Ruairi feel free to tell me if I’m wrong). Dividing the space with a wall like that essentially makes the back wall anechoic and uses the “other room” as a chamber to let low end that makes it though bounce around, lose energy, and be refiltered as it renters the room so it doesn’t make it back to listening position. There is much more to it of course. It also catches stray reflections, etc so they don’t make it back to listening.

Keep in mind my room is designed to sound as good as possible in the listening position for mastering so reflections that help it feel fun/good for clients on a sofa aren’t helpful to me! 

Synths are around because I like to continually remind myself how difficult finishing a record is and I find staying connected to playing makes me make much more musical mastering decisions!

author: BatMeckley
content:
Having a proper vocal booth for Vox and guitar cabs was life changing for me. Being able to make decisions on the way in by hearing what’s actually being recorded and not the sound in the room (without having to use headphones) is the single biggest luxury of my spot. 

I’m sure a guy like EV or Cian had enough miles at barefoot to go “whelp, this is not what I’m hearing right NOW, but when the guitarist stops playing I know it’ll sound like THIS” but that kind of guessing game always bummed me out.

author: Preston Lull
content:
Make sure to find a good luthier and get it set up well! Get it intonated (saddles, and nut height so you’re not pulling the strings out of tune in the first positions) and get the neck adjusted and action set. 
get it feeling GOOD to play.
#1 reason people don’t continue with guitar is that the setup on their guitar is wonky and they never even knew, they thought it was just hard to play

author: Preston Lull
content:
A lot of factory made guitars have fretboards of varying quality (maybe it’ll have subtle warps and waves in the wood up and down the neck) - if you’re having issues with playability beyond just getting a set-up maybe get the frets dressed and leveled out,
Long story short, if it doesn’t feel or sound good, you can always find a luthier (usually in a guitar repair shop) to help you out

author: BatMeckley
content:
In all seriousness engineers much better than I do it ALL the time. Most rooms there’s a pretty good amount of bleed and a good engineer knows how to separate what they’re hearing from what’s actually being recorded. It was just important to me when I bought a place that I didn’t have to. 

In my mind that’s one of the biggest selling points of digital guitar modeling is that what you hear is what you actually get, for better or worse.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: Not sure what you mean?  ...   the amount of signal is proportional to the decibel level of the source more than the preamp gain setting, and full orchestra is a loud beast.  Each channel is set so that FFF dynamics (barely) don't clip the preamp and the mix at unity and loud full orchestra is kissing into a brickwall limiter at -1db.  It might push the loudest peaks at 3-6db in reduction. But the RMS is all over the place. Final mix probably close to -20 LUFS program average.

author: Zack Hames
content: First synth that truly inspired me and felt like an instrument. I played in a noise pop/ industrial band and just played this through a 4x12 with a reverb and delay pedal and it was so exciting and performative, almost like guitar or drums. There’s obviously so much complex patching you can do but my favorite trick was to run the noise generator through the one of the oscillators so it would shape and modulate the noise rather than simply give you PSSSHHHH on top of a square wave. I’ll send the exact patching later, it’s quite simple.

content: Yeah, the way that thing distorts internally is magic. Also another thing that helped me with synths in general is treating it LIKE a guitar. A lot of synths are recorded direct, and that’s usually the intent, but guitars are almost never recorded direct completely clean with 0 effects or tone shaping. Running synths through pedals and amps and FX really opens the world for anyone struggling with “synth production”

author: peterlabberton
content:
My future setup. Will of course need to adapt as I get in the room and listen, but I'm excited *and* need to minimize downtime between studios, so I'm mapping stuff out as best I can so I can hit the ground running.

I'm thinking I'll build some fiberglass/rockwool panels on stands (the four panels freestanding by the mix position) and mimic some of the idea behind the attack wall: kill reflections closer to the listening position rather than at the walls. This way I can keep the fireplace and windows from being covered up, and have some gobos to move around when needed for tracking. The small desk to the left of the mix position will be a rack for gear, the large rectangular thingy in the upper right will be an upright piano. I'll pack in some DIY tube traps around the monitors, and hang two 4'x2' panels I already own over the mix position. I'll also put two slightly smaller panels over the drums, and two more on the wall behind the drums. The french doors and the sliding doors to the closet behind the couch will have heavy curtains.

author: Maxim
content:
I’d wholeheartedly recommend the Focal Clear MG. Out of the box they were my favorite in the 1-1.5k price range. I tested the HEDDs, Airpod Max, Audeze LCD-X and own the M50s and HD650s. 

I was looking for the headphone that gave me the best assortment of detail, fun, space, and „translation“ to speakers out of the box (without extra eq or another amp to power it outside of my UAD interface). 

For my taste the Focals fit that perfectly. Even hooked up to my laptop directly the sound was extremely fun, detailed and useful in making decisions. 

Also the look, comfort, travel case and extra pads are a nice touch. Only negative for me was the cable being a bit too short in a recording/moving around in a studio setting. But I wouldn’t use them for that anyways. 

AirPod Max (with noise canceling) would probably be second. They just lack the finer details and deep bass for me. 

Then the LCD-x (they are technically better than the Airpods but I wouldn’t prefer the LCDs in a real world setting. Only in the studio with some eq added).

HEDDs I so heavily disliked it wasn’t even funny. The UAD Interface can’t power them properly and they just sounded like a crappy and weird set of nearfield speakers playing from either side of your ear. Can’t even explain it.

author: peterlabberton
content:
This is the kind of nerdy tweaky shit I think this discord will appreciate: got my lil S1 control surface a few days ago, and used setting it up as an excuse to also play around with the arrangement of my tiny desk, and add some EQ to my monitors.

Tried the S1 behind my keyboard (too deep and potential for more reflections), and off to my left (weird neck craning all day), and landed here for now. Then busted out a mirror and angled my desk to avoid any reflections from the monitors at the listening position. Shot the room again and popped this EQ on the output in UAD Console (it’s finally good for something!!), and am very pleased with the new arrangement. 🎉

Ruairi might have a fit with this EQ curve, but I’m ABing it in and out and it’s definitely helpful, until I get my act together and build some membranes!

author: cian riordan
content:
So here’s the roundup on my dumb drum thing. This is a scrappy little experiment on my part to see if I can get a convincing drum sound in my little drum room. Before starting this, I had the idea in my mind that if a room is good for mixing, it must be good for recording! *Insert Game Show Buzzer* I ran into many of the things I didn’t like about the Barefoot Studio B Live room — and those things were exaggerated by a factor of 10. First of all, my room is very dead by design. It treats me great in mixing, but made for a real challenge when trying to get *some* sort of drum personality. I was also working with a pretty shitty old premier kit that hadn’t seen the light of day in half a decade. Shitty cymbals, very quickly tuned heads — I wasn’t setting myself up for success… but whatever.

The setup was a little ridiculous (minus a few utilitarian pieces):
Kick: Beta 52 -> Scully 280
Snare: SM57 -> Scully 280
OH Mono: Coles 4038 -> Ampex 351 -> 1176 (not compressing, just to trim gain before ‘tools)
OH L/R: U67s -> UTA pre (thanks Matt!)
Kick Room: U47 -> UTA Pre (again…)

This is where I ended up, without mixing, and with some quick playing and utility EQ/balancing. No compression except a limiter to bring up the level. While the actual drums themselves don’t sound amazing, I really struggled with getting any sort of energy out of the drums… it all just got sucked out. 

Here are the results if you care (don’t judge my shitty playing)

I think if it do this again I would:
1) Have a better sounding kit. Turns out, shit in.. shit out. I knew this. We all know this. But here I am.
2) Maybe put some sheets of plywood around to create some surface in the room. Just give it some life.
3) Not use the Scully. It’s so hard to get them to not sound distorty… I just don’t have enough pres on hand to have clean path for everything. Mix studio living.

So it goes…

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I have a Hilo goes AES to speakers and as my send/capture for the Massive Passive...you can't see it here but there is a rack under the screen where it sits. I have a side car off the side (the walls look pretty tight but they are actually the unf*ck mass loaded vinyl L things, so the room opens up more behind them). The sidecar is back from those...its got a apogee symphony taking the ins for my synths (also not really pictured -- just hangarounds from my production days for the fun of it sometimes), Hazelrigg VLC in there too.

There is sorta a whole room behind the listening position...its 30 feet long with a floating wall for absorption about 15 feet in so the studio is like 13x15 but acoustically its larger if that makes sense.

I do use streamdeck...but mainly to switch quickly between the hot ref in Wavelab and my master. I've gotten deep into Applescript which essentially handles all of the other Wavelab processes...it's almost finished but my streamdeck will essentially just launch those applications to do what I need. So I'd say it's very useful, but the coding I've been able to do will render it sorta meaningless for me (though convienent, I use it for other things like navigating websites when doing client outreach, etc which is very handy and makes my workflow like an order of magnitude quicker).

Chair is hag capisco. I love it. Had a serious back injury when I was younger so I'm pretty dialed into having things be ergonomic and I find it's great. Actually kinda rather uncomfortable...in a good way. You can't really slouch. Took some getting used to but it's interesting

author: jmlongmusic
content:
Hey everyone! I’m new to the community - really enjoying it so far. This will be a long post asking for some studio build advice — I hope that’s ok. Please just let me know if there’s a better thread for this sort of thing. 

I’d be extremely grateful for any feedback! Here’s some info: 

- I am currently moving my home studio to this basement space that is about 400 SQ feet. Concrete floor and walls except for the front wall shown in this picture - that is drywall as it separates the rest of the basement. 

- The ceiling joists are exposed and are about 7.5” deep. 

- My primary function for this room will be mixing, but I will also be doing smaller overdubs like piano and vocals. 

Currently, after painting the walls and floor, my plan is as follows: 
- Stuff the ceiling joists with insulation — probably Safe N Sound… thoughts on that choice? 

- Cover the joists with fabric from Gilford of Maine. 

- Figure out how to drill into concrete 😂 Then put panels everywhere. Most of my panels are about 4” thick and are comprised of the safe n sound insulation. 
- Put some big rugs down but also leave a bit of the concrete exposed if possible cuz I like the look. Haha 

- My monitoring set up is NS10M’s (don’t laugh) with an Avantone CLA-100 amp and a PreSonus T10 sub. I’ve got an Apollo 8 Duo and Apollo Twin X Quad. 

That concludes my plan so far. Am I on the right track? 😳 

I really appreciate any feedback you’re willing to give. 🙏

author: itMIGHTbeNICK
content:
This is my humble home setup in the corner of my bedroom. There’s nothing glamorous here. While I’m still building out the room downstairs and things have been at a hault due to some financial difficulties I won’t get into. I’m doing most of my work right here these days if I can’t get studio time at my buddys space. I’m incredibly proud of the mixes and masters I’ve been able to do in this little corner. I set up some gobos and tube traps I have in the closet when I’m getting deep into the mix and it’s all been working out as best as it can for the situation at hand.
NS10’s have the cap mod. 

When I need to track my guitar amps I completely isolate them with long cables and treatment directly in my closet or I will close off the bathroom and treat them in there as well as capture the natural reflection in our bathroom. My wife and kids are so incredibly sensitive and generous to me during this time to even let me still be able to work and make this happen while the studio build is on hold and we’re having to make things work.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yup! They're very similar in that regard, but still different. You can generally think of RM as the fast version of tremolo (volume modulation), in the way that FM synthesis is the fast version of vibrato (pitch modulation). Both techniques generate side bands through modulation rates that are in the audible range (> 20 Hz).

The difference between RM and tremolo is that tremolo is a uni-polar modulation and ring modulation is bipolar, which will generate different side bands. I'm a little fuzzy on the math of it these days, but if I remember correctly RM will generate negative side bands which are reflected at 0 Hz and start to travel back up the spectrum, whereas with AM they disappear when they get to 0 Hz.

Pop 'em in a frequency analyzer and watch the side bands go! Especially the RM. It's pretty informative.
